answers.answer: It is unusual to see myopia progressing in your 40s.  2 reasons could be early cataract and diabetes.  Nuclear sclerotic cataract (a yellowing and hardening of the central part of the lens) can cause an increase in myopia as the cataract develops.  Elevated blood sugar in diabetes can also cause onset or worsening of myopia.  These 2 conditions should be considered.  High myopia does increase the risk of retinal detachment and glaucoma; while these cannot be prevented, they can be detected and treated by your ophthalmologist.  You need to be examined by the EyeMD immediately if you have sudden light flashes or onset of many new floaters in either eye; these are symptoms of a possible retinal tear.  Glaucoma usually has no symptoms, but is diagnosed by with a careful exam of the optic nerve and other tests.  Tendency to high myopia is usually hereditary, and there is some evidence that hard contact lens wear may slow the progression.
